explanation:
1) MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_
   - Required because parse_cookies_string calls this function to store cookie name/value pairs. To determine MISRA violations about <string.h> calls you must inspect this function’s implementation and prototype: does it use standard string functions (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.), and if so, does it rely on the provided pointer parameters being NUL-terminated or does it always use the supplied length arguments? If it calls strlen/strcpy on the passed pointers (rather than using the explicit length arguments), it could read beyond the bounds of the substrings passed by parse_cookies_string unless parse_cookies_string ensures NUL termination in all cases.

2) MHD_connection_alloc_memory_
   - This helper is called (directly or indirectly) by MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_. Its implementation must be checked because it may perform memory allocation and memory copies (memcpy/memmove) or other string operations when moving/storing the provided name/value. You need to verify that any use of <string.h> functions in this allocator/copy path only accesses the exact ranges (using supplied lengths) and does not assume additional NUL termination beyond the bounds.

3) parse_cookie_header
   - This is the caller of parse_cookies_string. To fully reason about whether any string.h calls operate out-of-bounds you must know the provenance and contract of the str and str_len arguments: who allocates the buffer, whether it is writable, whether str_len correctly represents the buffer size, and whether any caller guarantees a terminating NUL at str[str_len] (or lack thereof). If the caller supplies a buffer smaller than str_len or if the buffer is not mutable, writes performed by parse_cookies_string (and any subsequent string.h usage in the callee chain) could be out-of-bounds. Checking parse_cookie_header shows how the input buffer is prepared and passed.
